document.docAuthor: Mauffray, William F. & Tennessen, Kenneth J.
document.masterDocTitle: A Catalogue and Historical Study of the Odonata of Ecuador

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A Catalogue and Historical Study of the Odonata of Ecuador

bibRefCitation.author: Machado, A. B. M.
bibRefCitation.refString: Machado, A. B. M. (2004) Studies on neotropical Protoneuridae. 15. Amazoneura gen. nov. with a description of A. juruaensis sp. nov. (Odonata, Zygoptera). Revista Brasileira de Zoologia, 21 (2), 333 - 336. https: // doi. org / 10.1590 / S 0101 - 81752004000200029

subSubSection.paragraph: Shade-dwelling, dark damselflies that tend to remain perched ( Fig. 32 ); for identification, see the papers by Machado (2001 , 2004 , 2009b ). Habitats are seepage areas and slow, muddy, small streams in forest. Two of the three known species occur in Ecuador ; the nymphs of this genus are unknown.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 32.
Amazoneura westfalli
♂, ECUADOR, Orellana Province, small stream on road to Carachupa Pakcha, S of Rt. E20, 30 x 2013; photo K. J. Tennessen.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Amazoneura ephippigera (Selys, 1886)
. Publ. Recs. ECU: Machado (2000) , (L05), Pessacq (2008) , (H08), (P11), (H14); OR : Tennessen (1996b) , Daigle (1996), von Ellenrieder & Garrison (2011) . Also BRA, PER: (L05), (H08), (P11).

Note: The distinctness of
A. westfalli
from
A. ephippigera
is questionable, as the male cerci are nearly identical; more study should be devoted to these taxa.
